meta.title: Female reproductive system anatomy and histology

content:
Introduction

The female reproductive system consists of the gonads (ovaries), internal genitalia (eg, fallopian tubes, uterus), and the external genitalia (eg, vulva, clitoris).  This article focuses on the function, anatomy, and histology of each component of the female reproductive system.

Ovaries



The ovaries are paired structures located posterolaterally to the uterus within the ovarian fossa on the lateral walls of the pelvis, bilaterally.  They are suspended superiorly by the mesovarium, medially by the uteroovarian ligament, and laterally by the suspensory ligament of the ovary.  The suspensory ligament of the ovary, also known as the infundibulopelvic ligament, is a fold of peritoneum that attaches the ovary to the pelvic sidewall and contains the ovarian artery, ovarian vein, lymphatics, and nerves (

figure 1
).



The 2 functions of the ovary are to produce mature oocytes for reproduction and to produce sex steroids (eg, estrogen, progesterone) for secondary sexual characteristics.

Blood supply



The ovaries are supplied blood primarily through the ovarian arteries, which originate from the abdominal aorta.  However, they also receive blood from an ascending branch of the uterine artery.  Blood is removed from the ovaries through the ovarian veins: the right ovarian vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava, whereas the left ovarian vein drains into the left renal vein (

figure 2
).

Nerve supply



The ovaries receive autonomic innervation from the ovarian plexus, which is derived from the renal and aortic plexuses.

Lymphatic drainage



The ovaries drain lymph predominantly to the paraaortic lymph nodes, although some lymph is drained to the external and internal iliac lymph nodes (

figure 3
).

Histology



The ovary is composed of 2 major portions, the outer cortex and the central medulla.



The outermost cortex is lined by a single layer of cuboidal cells (ie, ovarian surface epithelium), which is a modified mesothelium that is continuous with the peritoneum.  Within the cortex is ovarian stroma with interspersed ovarian follicles at different developmental stages (

figure 4
).  The mature follicle consists of an oocyte (germ cell) encircled by granulosa cells and theca cells, which support the oocyte throughout follicle development.



The central medulla of the ovary is predominantly composed of blood vessels and nerves within loose connective tissue.

Fallopian tubes



The fallopian tubes (oviducts) are approximately 10-12 cm long and extend bilaterally from the uterine cornua.  They are divided into 3 sections: the isthmus, ampulla, and infundibulum (which contains fimbriae).  The primary function of the fallopian tube is to capture an ovulated oocyte with the fimbriae, provide a site of fertilization, and transport the zygote to the uterus.

Blood supply



The fallopian tubes receive blood through the anastomoses of the ovarian artery with an ascending branch of the uterine artery.

Nerve supply



The fallopian tubes receive autonomic innervation via the ovarian and uterine plexuses.

Lymphatic drainage



Lymph from the fallopian tubes drains primarily to the paraaortic nodes (via ovarian vessels) and iliac lymph nodes (via the uterine vessels) (

figure 3
).

Histology



The fallopian tube has 3 layers: the mucosa, the muscularis (composed of an inner circular layer and an outer longitudinal layer), and the serosa.  The mucosa is lined with ciliated columnar cells and secretory cells.  The zygote moves through the fallopian tube toward the uterus for implantation via peristaltic contractions of the muscularis layer and the coordinated beating of the cilia, which produces laminar flow.

Uterus



The uterus is a muscular organ that consists of the fundus, the uterine body, the isthmus (site of fallopian tube insertion), and the cervix.  The uterus is covered by a sheet of peritoneum extending from the uterus and upper cervix to the pelvic sidewall, known as the broad ligament (

figure 6
).  It is divided into 3 parts:



  • Mesosalpinx:  Descends from the fallopian tube.
  • Mesovarium:  Inferior to the mesosalpinx, covers the ovarian hilum.
  • Mesometrium:  The largest portion of the broad ligament that lies inferior to the mesovarium, lateral from the uterus to external iliac vessels, and anterior to the proximal round ligament.


The primary functions of the uterus are to be the site of implantation and to support fetal development.  In addition, the innermost lining of the uterus (endometrium) undergoes monthly shedding and regeneration in the menstrual cycle under the control of fluctuating hormones (eg, estrogen, progesterone).

Blood supply



The uterus is supplied blood through the uterine arteries, which are branches of the internal iliac artery.  The ureter runs close to the uterine artery, which places the ureter at risk for iatrogenic injury during hysterectomies.  The ureter dives under the uterine artery ("water under the bridge") in the cardinal ligaments at the site of uterine vessel ligation (

figure 7
).  The uterine venous plexus drains into the internal iliac veins.

Nerve supply



The uterus receives autonomic innervation through the uterovaginal plexus as well as through sympathetic (via T10-L2) and parasympathetic fibers (S2-S4).

Lymphatic drainage



Lymph drainage of the uterus primarily occurs through the external iliac arteries, although some drainage (primarily of the fundus) occurs through the paraaortic lymph nodes.

Histology



The uterus is composed of 3 layers of tissue:



  • Endometrium:  The endometrium is the inner lining of the uterus and consists of the functional layer (shed during menstruation) and the regenerative basal layer.  The endometrial mucosa consists of endometrial glands (lined by columnar cells) with surrounding stroma.  The endometrium is dynamic, undergoing changes that are stimulated by estrogen and progesterone during phases of the menstrual cycle.
    • In the follicular phase (estrogen-dominant phase), the endometrium proliferates and thickens (
      image 1
      ).
    • In the luteal phase (progesterone-dominant phase), the endometrium differentiates into secretory endometrium (via spiral vessel coiling and large intracytoplasmic glycogen vacuole deposition within the cells), preparing it for implantation (
      image 2
      ).  If implantation does not occur, progesterone levels fall and the uterine lining sheds (menses).
  • Myometrium:  The myometrium comprises the majority of the uterus and is made of thick smooth muscle, which is responsible for uterine contractions during delivery.
  • Perimetrium:  The perimetrium is the outer serosal covering of the uterus, comprised of simple squamous epithelium.

Vagina



The vagina is a fibromuscular tube (about 7-10 cm in length) and part of the outflow tract (for menstrual outflow, giving birth) of the female reproductive system.  The upper two-thirds of the vagina are formed from the paramesonephric ducts, and the lower one-third is formed from the urogenital sinus.

Blood supply



The primary blood supply of the vagina is the vaginal artery.  The origin of the vaginal artery varies and can arise from the internal iliac artery or the uterine artery.  The vaginal venous plexus drains into the internal iliac artery.

Nerve supply



Innervation of the vagina is varied and is divided according to embryologic origin.  The upper two-thirds are innervated by autonomic fibers from the uterovaginal plexus, whereas the lower one-third is innervated by somatic fibers from the pudendal nerve (S2-S4).

Lymphatic drainage



Lymph from the upper 2/3 of the vagina is drained to the internal iliac lymph nodes, whereas the lower one-third drains to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

Histology



The vaginal wall is composed of 3 main layers:



  • Mucosa:  The mucosa is lined by nonkeratinized stratified epithelium, supported by a lamina propria rich in elastic and collagen fibers. 
  • Muscularis:  The muscularis is made up of 2 layers of smooth muscle (providing distensibility): the inner circular layer and the outer longitudinal layer.
  • Adventitia:  The adventitia is composed of connective tissue, which anchors the vagina to surrounding pelvic structures.

External genitalia (vulva)



The external genitalia include the mons pubis, labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, vestibule of the vagina, and greater vestibular glands (

figure 8
).  Structures of the external genitalia are derived from the genital tubercule (eg, labia majora and minora, clitoris) and the urogenital sinus (eg, vaginal vestibule, greater vestibular glands).

Blood supply



The external genitalia receive blood from the internal pudendal artery, which arises from the internal iliac artery and travels from the pudendal canal with the pudendal nerve.  The internal pudendal vein drains into the internal iliac vein.

Nerve supply



The external genitalia are innervated by somatic fibers from the pudendal nerve (S2-S4).  The pudendal nerve originates from the ventral rami of S2-S4 and passes between the piriformis and coccygeus muscles as it exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen.  It then reenters the pelvis near the ischial spine through the lesser sciatic foramen before dividing into its terminal branches.  Sensory branches innervate the external genitalia and skin around the anus and perineum.  Motor branches innervate the pelvic floor muscles and external urethral and anal sphincters.

Lymphatic drainage



Lymph from the vulva drains initially to the inguinofemoral nodes, which consist of a superficial inguinal node and a deeper femoral node (

Histology



The labia majora is composed of stratified squamous epithelium and sebaceous glands.  The labia minor is lined by a squamous epithelium with a thin keratin layer and contains fewer glands than the labia majora and no hair follicles.  The clitoris contains corpus cavernosum composed of erectile tissue.
